description: Cannabis product formulation and chemical analysis baseline questions

questions.question: What factors affect cannabinoid extraction efficiency in CO2 supercritical extraction?
questions.expectedAnswer: CO2 extraction efficiency factors: 1) Temperature (30-80°C optimal), 2) Pressure (200-300 bar), 3) Flow rate, 4) Extraction time, 5) Particle size of plant material, 6) Moisture content (<10%), 7) Co-solvents (ethanol), 8) Multiple extraction cycles, 9) Decarboxylation status, 10) Plant material quality and age.

questions.question: How do you calculate the bioavailability of THC in different delivery methods?
questions.expectedAnswer: THC bioavailability by method: 1) Smoking: 25-35%, onset 2-10 min, 2) Vaporizing: 40-60%, onset 2-10 min, 3) Sublingual: 20-35%, onset 15-45 min, 4) Oral: 4-20%, onset 30-120 min, 5) Topical: <1% systemic, 6) Rectal: 25-50%, onset 15-60 min. Calculate dose = (desired effect dose) / (bioavailability percentage).

questions.question: What storage conditions preserve cannabinoid stability in finished products?
questions.expectedAnswer: Cannabinoid stability requirements: 1) Temperature: <25°C, avoid heat, 2) Light: Dark storage, UV protection, 3) Oxygen: Minimal air exposure, nitrogen atmosphere, 4) Humidity: 55-65% RH for flower, <5% for extracts, 5) pH: Neutral conditions, 6) Container: Glass or appropriate barrier materials, 7) Avoid metal contact, 8) Regular potency testing.

questions.question: Which terpenes are most volatile during extraction and how to preserve them?
questions.expectedAnswer: Volatile terpenes and preservation: 1) Most volatile: Pinene, limonene, myrcene (low boiling points), 2) Preservation methods: Cold extraction (<40°C), 3) Steam distillation collection, 4) Fractional distillation, 5) Addition post-extraction, 6) Vacuum processing, 7) Short exposure times, 8) Proper storage in dark, cool conditions.

questions.question: What analytical methods are required for full cannabinoid profiling?
questions.expectedAnswer: Cannabinoid profiling methods: 1) HPLC-UV/DAD for potency, 2) LC-MS/MS for trace cannabinoids, 3) GC-MS for neutral forms, 4) Sample preparation: decarboxylation, extraction, 5) Reference standards for quantification, 6) Method validation (accuracy, precision, LOD/LOQ), 7) Quality controls, 8) Matrix-matched calibration.
